Good movie. It really rolled until the last hour: when a lot of the action went down is when it started to drag. A little dark, but their personal strength and vision were united. I really enjoyed some of these characters, even deCaprio, and I never like deCaprio. The 'regular' kids were awesome in their clips. The film could have had more of that, how the 3rd parties reacted. In film the best moments are others' reactions, like when the dolphins breached in the Big Blue. The high school kids' non-acting acting was a thing of beauty. Juxtaposing that with Sean Penn's gross character which was just over the top weird. I'm not saying that the state actors aren't degenerates, but that sociopathic narcissism is also a blind spot, not a Bond supervillain.

One Battle After Another is nothing more than a bloated piece of liberal propaganda masquerading as high art, pushing a dangerous narrative that romanticizes left-wing violence and portrays conservatives as cartoonish fascist villains. Paul Thomas Anderson crafts a fever dream where washed-up radicals bombing buildings and resisting immigration enforcement are depicted as sympathetic underdogs fighting a white supremacist dystopia, ignoring the real-world consequences of such extremism. With Leonardo DiCaprio's sweaty, incompetent protagonist shouting revolutionary slogans while enabling chaos, the film feels like an apologia for Antifa-style terrorism, especially ill-timed amid recent political violenceâ€”it's irresponsible and could inspire more division rather than entertain. Skip this three-hour preach fest; it's not satire, it's insidious Hollywood bias at its worst, glorifying losers who waste lives on misguided "resistance" instead of productive citizenship. 0/10â€”save your money for films that don't hate half the country.

Paul Thomas Anderson is married to Maya Rudolph and they have four daughters. This movie looks like a semi-autobiographical parody of their home life. PTA has made a few good films and one great one (There Will Be Blood), but his overall body of work is less than compelling and rarely anything one wants to see a second time.  Boogie Nights, for example, does not hold up over the decades. It's sophomoric, solipsistic, irrelevant. Does anyone want to sit through Magnolia again? The story itself looks like nonsense and mostly an excuse to shoot high powered weapons and blow things up. 
PTA should have retired after Phantom Thread.

The movie is based on Thomas Pynchon's novel, Vineland, which was one of counterculture Weather Underground revolutionary Timothy Leary's favorite books. DiCaprio's dad was a close friend of Leary's, and DiCaprio knew him too. DiCaprio owns the rights to Leary's biography and has spent a decade trying to make it into a movie. This film may be as close as he gets to telling a revolutionary story like that of the Weather Underground.
